The software's interaction with PDFs is limited, providing content that is mostly unhelpful. The summaries offered by the software fail to capture the key points. The answers to questions are only based on the content contained within the PDF itself, resulting in responses that are overly superficial and lack depth and core insights. If the PDF does not contain the answer to a question, the software refuses to respond. However, when chatting with PDFs or other document formats, the user's primary goal is to inquire about concepts they do not understand in order to expand their knowledge. Users should be able to ask for examples, request explanations in simpler language, and receive answers that are deep and comprehensive. This is what would truly be helpful.

Ok, let me start by saying, that I found the first few hours playing this game really fun, and if it weren‚Äôt for these issues that I‚Äôm about to talk about, I would probably be giving this a higher rating. I am a huge rogue like fan, started with Dead Cells, and now I have, like, twenty and counting. And when I saw that there seemed to be another one for the collection, I was extremely excited. I downloaded the game and found the beginning very fun, interesting leveling up mechanics, I was into it‚Ä¶

 ‚Ä¶Until I reached the level cap‚Ä¶ 

 Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong, I love a difficult game, but having to, basically, face the same brick wall with a different combination of these 50 levels, just trying to get some progress, having to face the same levels, with the same enemies. Now, I know a rogue like is supposed to be somewhat repetitive at some point in the progression. But this game reached that point, A LOT quicker than other titles I have played. If the developers added some level diversion, like those similar to that of Soul Knight, that would greatly extend the game‚Äôs ability to be entertaining for longer. 

 But, anyway, that all that I have to say about this game, the general game mechanics are nice, but the same levels and the same enemies without any diversion can get dull very quickly.

This app wants access to Screen Time Restrictions. If you don‚Äôt allow it the app becomes stuck in an endless loop until you agree.

The next time this happens is if you choose ‚ÄúLock Apps‚Äù or ‚ÄúConceal Apps‚Äù. It once again puts the app in an endless loop until you agree to give it Screen Time control. 

Importing videos is limited to 120 seconds. 

Deleting photos, you are prompted once before the delete becomes permanent. This app does not have a trash can, and no time limit such as 30 days to recover. Once deleted it is gone forever. 

On Screen Time access, the developer can issue a prompt that some features of the app will not function correctly without access but forcing the end user into an endless loop prompt until you agree to give it access does not inspire confidence or trust, it‚Äôs just sloppy coding and testing.

Fourth‚Äî the second recipe I found was missing crucial information. The first step was to prepare the caramelized nuts, and from the way it was set up, I was to add every ingredient to the nuts, including lettuce, cheese, oil, water, etc. Luckily, I found out I could click on the author's name and go to her site to find out what she really meant.

I don't need or want excess stuff in my recipes, so I too often need to rewrite them to make sense. Maybe authors should provide the recipes the way they like them and the traditional, streamlined versions.

I left this review based on my honest experience with the app. If you consider feedback or refund requests to be ‚Äúshady‚Äù or ‚Äúsuspicious,‚Äù that‚Äôs unfortunate. My mention of an Amazon gift card was simply sharing an experience I had with another developer. After Apple denied my refund, they kindly offered an alternative refund through PayPal. When PayPal wasn‚Äôt an option for me, they suggested a gift card as a goodwill gesture. This was an empathetic response, not something suspicious.

Regarding the purchase, my son accidentally made it. Initially, I thought the app seemed useful, but after further use, I realized it didn‚Äôt meet my needs. Had it been more effective, I would have gladly kept it. Instead of addressing my feedback, you ignored my last two emails and chose to publicly respond to my review in a way that felt like an attack.

To clarify, I never requested a gift card. I was simply sharing a past experience with another developer. Apple likely denied my refund because the app offers a free trial, and they may have assumed I had the opportunity to test it beforehand or could have prevented an accidental purchase with my child.

The app itself has clear limitations. While marketed as a habit tracker for weight, photos, water intake, and books read:
1.Only the weight and photo features actually track progress.
2.Water intake and books read are merely checklist items with no meaningful tracking functionality, such as visual charts or progress records like the weight and photo features offer. Setting a daily target doesn‚Äôt provide a visual tracking chart or record, so it‚Äôs not truly a tracker.
3.The app only allows setting general reminders at specific times, but there are no personalized reminders for individual tasks, making the task management feature impractical.
4.The only customization offered for tasks is the ability to change their icon colors, which adds no real functionality beyond aesthetics.

In reality, the app functions more like a to-do list with a photo and weight tracker‚Äînothing more‚Äîat a price of $5.99.

It‚Äôs important to note that you were the one who publicly exposed this situation, not me. You falsely claimed that I requested a gift card, which I did not. In my emails, I raised concerns about the app‚Äôs missing features and requested specific improvements multiple times, none of which you addressed.

Had Apple refunded me, I wouldn‚Äôt have contacted you at all. Instead of considering users‚Äô explanations, you assume the worst and dismiss legitimate concerns. Furthermore, handling this issue publicly on the App Store rather than privately is unprofessional.

I don‚Äôt understand the point of telling me you won‚Äôt engage further via email while continuing to publicly attack me on the App Store. If you truly had no interest in further discussion, you wouldn‚Äôt be responding at all‚Äîespecially not in a public forum. It seems that rather than resolving issues, you are more interested in discrediting users publicly.

Also, I find it strange that Apple keeps publishing my review, only for it to mysteriously disappear later. That seems highly suspicious.

I don‚Äôt owe you an explanation for my son‚Äôs accidental purchase. That was something I addressed in my appeal to Apple, not to you. It‚Äôs clear that instead of addressing real concerns, you‚Äôre more focused on publicly attacking users.

If you continue this behavior, I won‚Äôt engage further. You can keep the one-star review, but your public responses are unprofessional. I won‚Äôt reply anymore‚Äîit‚Äôs evident you prefer public confrontation over resolving issues privately.

Response to dev below original review. 

Original review:
Promoted as 1 year free trial of premium. After download, the only available promo is $.99 for first month, $4.99/mo thereafter. Further, the dev promotes an annual subscription for $49 as 50% off. If $4.99 is the standard monthly price, how is $49/yr equal to 50% off. These are signs of manipulative marketing tactics. 

Devs who employ these tactics often promise access to the most advanced AI models for low cost. In actuality they‚Äôre providing access to a low-cost version of  GPT3/3.5, sometimes fine tuned to evade questions about the exact model version. Dishonest devs using these manipulative tactics to maximize their profits is all too common. These devs should not be trusted with your money nor your data‚Ä¶ avoid them. You‚Äôre far better off using the free versions of ChatGPT, Perplexity or other reputable solutions. 

That said, people make mistakes. If the above points were simply mistakes that the dev rectifies, I will amend my rating/review.

Response to dev: 
New app promos on AppAdvice launch daily at 10:30am CST. I downloaded and attempted to take advantage of the offer within an hour of the promo launching on AppAdvice. Further, time-limited and limited seats, are not the same. ALL promotions are time-limited by definition. The promo on AppAdvice says nothing about limited seats (eg: ‚Äúoffer limited to first 1,000 users‚Äù). Further, promos on AppAdvice state, ***THIS PROMOTION IS EXPIRED*** once the offer expires, usually 12-24hrs after launch. AppAdvice still shows your promo active three days after it launched. Why are you still promoting the offer if it expired within a few hours of launch??

Regarding the price/discount % discrepancy‚Ä¶ you might want to use your own app to ask GPT to help you correctly frame promo/discount language. This is entry level stuff, and based on the scathing reviews and your responses, MarComm is not a strength.

Again, these are tactics frequently used by dishonest devs‚Ä¶ honest devs generally take the long view, going over and above to take responsibility and make it right. Dishonest devs take no responsibility and generally make excuses. If it looks like a duck‚Ä¶

I got this app after seeing it mentioned in App Advice. I was really annoyed by the onboarding process and then having to review the app before I could use it. Not the smartest way to have your customers start off‚Ä¶annoyed. The app is very simply laid out, but a few things are confusing. Some of the contrasts in colors need to be more pronounced so people with vision problems can see. The calculated unit dosing on the syringe should have more contrast from the syringe tick marks. The label under the syringe on the right, ‚Äúvial contains X doses‚Äù is VERY confusing. It implies the calculated results, given the water and peptide strength input, will give you a glass vial sitting on the counter with X (in my case 100) doses. That is totally not correct given my input of .5 mL Bac Water and .5 mL of 10 mg Tirz. So, I think the dev is trying to emphasize the syringe has 100 potential doses based on the number of tick marks on it? But, that is not necessary and is just plain confusing. Plus, the wording in that location is just more visual clutter since it is not useful information pertaining to the calculation just completed. Also, the last input you make, the peptide dose you want, should have the option for mcg OR mg. For example, for Tirzepatide, I will use mg. It is unlikely I will ever go lower than mg strength, even microdosing it. But for Sema or Reta, I will definitely use mcg. So, being able to choose would be nice, instead of having to do the math myself before plugging in the numbers. As far as what I like? I LOVE that you can save your calculations in a history for quick and easy reference. It is nice to have this information available to pull up quickly. It would be great to have an information library on various peptides and what they all do. I am not sure if the dev has that kind of time though. Nice job in general!

Does OpenAI delete personal messages? Deletion doesn‚Äôt count as data collection, but processing data through your app or services does. The data usage issue persists. Other companies use the App Store‚Äôs ‚Äúusage data‚Äù marker, but this developer avoids mentioning it. Data collection is data collection, and the anonymity of the usage data remains unmentioned. 

Transparency surpasses data collection for me. Apple offers transparency, but companies overlook it due to the absence of ‚Äúpersonal data.‚Äù Your in-app AI, regardless of processing or deletion, constitutes data collection, even if brief and self-resolving.




Previous review:

Privacy policy doesn‚Äôt align with the App Store‚Äôs guidelines: no data collection. It saves conversations with AI and collects ‚Äúusage data.‚Äù Both can be displayed in the App Store as ‚Äúdata not linked to you.‚Äù I‚Äôd like to review other exceptional companies‚Äô privacy policies, but I‚Äôm starting to understand the loophole.
